translated: Jātaka🔽The Collection of Birth Stories (Jātakas)
The Chapter of Gandhāri
The Birth Story of Kummāsa-Piṇḍika
“There is nothing strange in the sight of the Buddha,
Service to the Buddhas is not rare;
For the sake of a dry, saltless meal,
Look at the fruit of Kummāsa-Piṇḍika.
These many elephants, cows, and horses,
Wealth, grain, and the entire earth;
These women who are like celestial nymphs,
Look at the fruit of Kummāsa-Piṇḍika.”
“Again and again, great king,
You speak verses, lord of Kosala;
I ask you, O augmenter of the kingdom,
Why you shine with intense joy?”
“In this very city,
I was in a certain family;
I was a servant,
a wage-earner, restrained by virtue.
As I was leaving for work,
I saw four ascetics;
Endowed with conduct and virtue,
cool and free from defilements.
Placing my faith in them,
sitting on a leaf mat;
I gave the Buddha a lump of sugar,
with a joyful heart.
By that wholesome deed,
this is the kind of fruit I have;
I enjoy this sovereignty,
this prosperous and excellent earth.”
“Giving, enjoy, and be not heedless,
Turn the wheel, lord of Kosala!
Be not a sinner, O king,
Uphold the Dhamma, lord of Kosala!”

analyzed: sā uham tat eva punar punar
translated: “So again and again,
I will go to the delightful Vaṭuma,
The noble conduct in the excellent Kosala,
The arahants are pleasing to see.
Like a queen, like a celestial maiden,
You shine in the midst of the assembly of nāgas!
What good deed did you do,
By what are you so beautiful in the excellent Kosala?”
“Khattiya of the Ambaṭṭha clan,
I was a slave of another,
Self-controlled, living righteously,
Virtuous, of good character.
When the alms-food was being distributed,
I gave to a wandering monk;
Joyful, delighted, I myself,
This is the fruit of that deed for me.”
The Kummāsapiṇḍi Jātaka is the tenth.
